messages.subject: Re: Chinese Fakes
messages.msgSnippet: Right Gordon -- it s just a function of the reply tab here.  There is a tendency to continue under the same header instead of starting a new topic as the
messages.messageBody:
Right Gordon -- it's just a function of the reply tab here. There is
a tendency to continue under the same header instead of starting a
new topic as the threads run in continuous column rather than divided
into topic columns. I think we're just so used to it we don't notice.
Pete Klein

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, This is an NBTHK European and American Branch translation. I am doing the Mito Kinko articles – should already be out, or soon to be out  -- for the
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,



This is an NBTHK European and American Branch translation. I am doing the
Mito Kinko articles  should already be out, or soon to be out -- for the
American Branch and Higo articles for the European Branch to be shared with
the American Branch, so, join up. I should have the Hirata article finished
in a week or so, but I do not know when it will be put out.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Richard Turner
Sent: Saturday, October 14, 2006 9:53 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?



Gordon, will that be a NBTHK publication, or like the last book you
translated that was sold through Harry Watson and the JSSUS ?, or is
this for the NTHK ?

Just curious how it will be made available.

Rich

Gordon Robson wrote:
>
> Thanks, but let's not get started on kodogu -- it's a nightmare. I am
> presently translating a piece by Fukushi sensei on the Higo Hirata School.
> There is only one known signed piece and probably three generations of
> Hirata Hikozo. However, in the article Fukushi sensei admits that he
> cannot
> tell the difference from one generation to the next and so lumps
> everything
> together as first generation. And, this is the easy stuff.
>
> Gordon
>
>

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, but let’s not get started on kodogu – it’s a nightmare. I am presently translating a piece by Fukushi sensei on the Higo Hirata School. There is
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, but lets not get started on kodogu  its a nightmare. I am
presently translating a piece by Fukushi sensei on the Higo Hirata School.
There is only one known signed piece and probably three generations of
Hirata Hikozo. However, in the article Fukushi sensei admits that he cannot
tell the difference from one generation to the next and so lumps everything
together as first generation. And, this is the easy stuff.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of klepet33319
Sent: Saturday, October 14, 2006 8:54 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?



Gordon -- well put. I tend to believe that a big part of the problem
is that so few of us have venues to learn in person that the reliance
on books overshadows the fact that you cannot learn to recognize the
nuances of hataraki from pictures. The details are learned by hands on
study (OK -- that's loosely put LOL) and need guidance from those with
great experience. To paraphrase what you said, get thee to a good show
or study group as often as possible.
PS: The same goes for the study of tosogu.





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: any comments about this sword?
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon -- well put.  I tend to believe that a big part of the problem is that so few of us have venues to learn in person that the reliance on books
messages.messageBody:
Gordon -- well put. I tend to believe that a big part of the problem
is that so few of us have venues to learn in person that the reliance
on books overshadows the fact that you cannot learn to recognize the
nuances of hataraki from pictures. The details are learned by hands on
study (OK -- that's loosely put LOL) and need guidance from those with
great experience. To paraphrase what you said, get thee to a good show
or study group as often as possible.
PS: The same goes for the study of tosogu.

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, More troubling to me than the background of this sword is the penchant for many to get a little knowledge and then go crazy about something they have
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,



More troubling to me than the background of this sword is the penchant for
many to get a little knowledge and then go crazy about something they have
bought, even to the point of making up stories about it. Ive had numerous
individuals come up and ask me what I think of the quality of utsuri in
their blade, the amount of kinsuji, or to comment on the beauty of the
chikei, when none of the features were present. Its as if learning jargon
is taking the place of actual study  hands on study with good swords that
actual have some of these features. Then, it would not be possible for there
to be a market for these Chinese swords.



I might add that I myself, and even Yoshikawa sensei, have been sent e-mails
or letters from Thailand, Indonesia and who knows where else asking us to
either buy or to comment on this garbage. In each case I have told the
individual exactly what they have, if they bought them, they should report
the seller for fraud, or if they are the seller, warning them that they can
be prosecuted for attempting to perpetrate a fraud. Unfortunately, people
are still being taken. I would hope that when Bob Benson or anyone else puts
on a display of top quality pieces somewhere in the States, everyone takes
the opportunity to go and learn.



Just my morning rant.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Saturday, October 14, 2006 1:35 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?



Hi all -

One of the now-famous "Chinese" Japanese swords came to me for opinion this
week. Talking to the fellow prior to the visit, I felt he had to be
describing a "ringer." You wouldn't believe what he all saw in that sword
and how excited he was about this "ancient" sword! I did ask if he wanted
"the truth" about if when he came over, and he said yes. It took a couple
hours and some show-and-tell to convince him. (He swore some Japanese
offered him $10K for this sword six months back!)

My question here today...this sword had the typical "etched" hada that you
could see from across the room. Has anyone figured out if these swords are
being actually "forged and acid etched" or if this so-called "hada" is
applied and etched (probably similar to fake damascus)? I couldn't say one
way or the other 100% but suspect it is "applied." The nakago looked raw and
certainly not something that even a blacksmith would make. Odd kanji, etc.,
and unfinished.

Comments?

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Ann-Marie
To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, October 13, 2006 11:10 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?

this sword has never been on ebay. and yes there are many fakes that look
similar that are on ebay.

and some said it must be chinese fake and I believe. Many of this kind is on
the market.
Sorry regards,
Eckhardt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: any comments about this sword?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all - One of the now-famous Chinese Japanese swords came to me for opinion this week. Talking to the fellow prior to the visit, I felt he had to be
messages.messageBody:
Hi all -

One of the now-famous "Chinese" Japanese swords came to me for opinion this week. Talking to the fellow prior to the visit, I felt he had to be describing a "ringer." You wouldn't believe what he all saw in that sword and how excited he was about this "ancient" sword! I did ask if he wanted "the truth" about if when he came over, and he said yes. It took a couple hours and some show-and-tell to convince him. (He swore some Japanese offered him $10K for this sword six months back!)

My question here today...this sword had the typical "etched" hada that you could see from across the room. Has anyone figured out if these swords are being actually "forged and acid etched" or if this so-called "hada" is applied and etched (probably similar to fake damascus)? I couldn't say one way or the other 100% but suspect it is "applied." The nakago looked raw and certainly not something that even a blacksmith would make. Odd kanji, etc., and unfinished.

Comments?

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] any comments about this sword?
messages.msgSnippet: Granted the tang has that Chinese pickled look, but otherwise it looks like a real katana to me in a battered WW2 shingunto koshirae.  Need better closeup
messages.messageBody:
Granted the tang has that "Chinese pickled" look, but otherwise it looks like a real katana to me in a battered WW2 shingunto koshirae. Need better closeup images of the tsuba etc etc to study the finer detail. Also some carefully chosen closeups of the blade.

While I'm here, a couple years back I got a call from a man who had found me through the local Japanese Consul General's office here in Oz. He was a collector, had 25 swords, and had been collecting for three years!! Every one of his swords was a Chinese "creation". Disappointing for sure.

Barry Thomas.
